Trevon Diggs faces uncertain but flexible next step



Trevon Diggs stood at the center of the Cowboys’ defensive plans not long ago, a playmaker trusted to change games with instinct and nerve. On Tuesday, that chapter closed abruptly. Dallas decided to waive the veteran cornerback, ending a relationship that once symbolized confidence in youth, swagger, and long term belief. The move landed quietly but carried weight across the league, especially given Diggs’ recent contract history and name recognition.The decision did not come out of nowhere. Tension had lingered for months, fueled by frustration over injuries, recovery timelines, and availability. Dallas weighed performance against potential and chose a clean break before the season’s final week. For Diggs, it marked a sharp pivot point at age 27, when careers often demand clarity more than patience.The financial mechanics explain why this release feels calculated rather than emotional. Any team claiming Diggs on waivers would have to absorb his remaining $472,222 game check, plus $58,823 if he suits up in Week 18. NFL Network’s Tom Pelissero noted that this obligation “makes it likely he clears waivers and then will become a free agent.”That outcome gives Diggs control without delay, allowing him to sign immediately rather than wait for the new league year.There is also no guaranteed money left on his deal beyond this season, a detail that made Dallas comfortable acting now. One source told ESPN’s Todd Archer the release stemmed from “a culmination of events, including performance.” Archer added that Diggs was “likely a candidate to be released after the season, which would have opened up roughly $12 million in cap space” for the Cowboys. The front office simply chose timing over optics.Injuries shaped much of Diggs’ recent story. He opened the year on the Physically Unable to Perform list following January knee surgery, then battled a second knee issue and a concussion from an at home incident. In eight games, he logged 25 tackles without a pass breakup or interception, a stark contrast to his All Pro peak.Still, league evaluators remember the corner who once led the NFL with 11 interceptions and changed coverage plans every Sunday. Diggs has hired David Mulugheta to guide the next phase, signaling intent rather than retreat. Article Title: Jason Kelce rips Josh Allen for rushed throw on failed two-point try in Bills’ one-point loss to Eagles
Article Text:
Jason Kelce offered blunt criticism of Josh Allen after the Bills lost 13 to 12 to the Eagles, pointing to a rushed throw on a failed two point conversion. Allen admitted he missed the play and took responsibility. Despite the loss, Buffalo clinched a playoff spot, though concerns remain about late game execution heading into postseason play.

Jason Kelce criticism of Josh Allen highlights late game execution

The final seconds in Philadelphia left little room for nuance, and the missed two point conversion quickly became the defining moment of the Bills’ one point loss. Josh Allen had already carried Buffalo back into the game with his legs, but the final throw told a harsher story. The play lingered into the following day, turning a narrow defeat into a league wide talking point.What kept the moment alive was not the miss itself, but how directly it was addressed. Former Eagles center Jason Kelce offered an unfiltered breakdown that reflected how players see mistakes when the margin is razor thin. His comments shifted the conversation from sympathy to accountability.Buffalo’s loss came after a strange night. Allen struggled early, then surged late with two rushing touchdowns that gave the Bills a chance to steal the game. The failed conversion erased that effort and handed Philadelphia a 13 to 12 win. While the Bills still secured a playoff spot, the ending exposed how little separates success from regret.Speaking on NFL on ESPN, Kelce did not soften his assessment. “He did (rush the throw),” Kelce said. “To his credit, he was pressured a little bit. ... I guarantee he's watching that and he knows himself, 'Damn, I got to make that throw.'” The remark landed because it echoed what many quarterbacks admit privately after film review.Allen did not deflect blame either. After the game, he said, “Yeah, I just missed. It just comes down to us executing, making one more play than they did. And obviously you saw that we didn't make that last play.” The honesty matched the moment and reinforced his leadership.Outside voices were less forgiving. Colin Cowherd questioned Buffalo’s postseason ceiling, saying, “I think Denver will beat them (the Bills). I think Jacksonville would beat them… Yeah, I can see the Buffalo being a one-and-done team. I've had them in the Herd Hierarchy around 8,9,10. It's just hard for me.”Still, context matters. Allen finished the season with 3,668 passing yards, 25 passing touchdowns, and 14 rushing scores. The Bills ranked among the league’s best offenses. The missed throw hurt, but the larger test now shifts to whether Buffalo can respond when the stakes rise again in January.Also Read: Patrick Mahomes’ injury recovery takes powerful turn as teen fighting rare disease steps up to inspire him
Article Summary: Jason Kelce offered blunt criticism of Josh Allen after the Bills lost 13 to 12 to the Eagles. Kelce pointed to a rushed throw on a failed two point conversion. Allen admitted he missed the play and took responsibility. Despite the loss, Buffalo clinched a playoff spot.

Article Title: Shedeur Sanders jewelry collection: Inside Browns QB’s $170K worth legendary chain, custom watch, and personalized pendant
Article Text:
(Image 1 via Getty: Shedeur Sanders' chain, Image 2 and 3 via Instagram: Shedeur Sanders)

Shedeur Sanders massive diamond chains with personalized pendants

Heisman Trophy recipient Shedeur Sanders owns a custom-made Audemars Piguet Royal Oak 15500 diamond watch

Like father, like son. NFL legend Deion Sanders became the NFL Draft’s first fashion icon by wearing a monochrome tracksuit and glistening gold jewelry when the Atlanta Falcons picked him fifth overall in 1989. Years later, his son, Shedeur Sanders, wore a massive ‘Legendary’ chain reportedly worth over $100K to the 2025 NFL Draft.Cleveland Browns rookie quarterback Shedeur Sanders is known for his extravagant jewelry collection, from the 2025 NFL Draft to his popular watch flex celebration [particularly flashing a custom-made Audemars Piguet Royal Oak 15500 diamond watch].By late 2025, the former Colorado Buffaloes signal caller’s net worth was estimated at about $8 million, earned through major NIL deals in college and his rookie contract with Cleveland. Now, let’s look at his jewelry collection.Designed by Tajia Diamonds, the “Legendary” chain is a massive, diamond-encrusted custom piece created in 48 hours. The chain reportedly costs $100K. The statement piece features 71.7 carats of VVS diamonds, with 43.5 carats in a custom Cuban link chain and a 28.2-carat diamond pendant spelling out “Legendary.” The large iced-out silver chain also features his personal brand, $$2.Back in his Colorado Buffaloes days, Sanders wore a thin, square-blocked diamond chain with a comparatively small “Legendary” pendant. “Legendary” was written in a Microsoft Word art font.Sanders later switched to a double-layered, thick diamond silver chain with a “2” pendant reportedly made by Saki Diamonds. “2” was his college football jersey number. Then came a thick Cuban link diamond chain with a heavily diamond-encrusted “$$” pendant. He once shared a photo on Instagram with a silver Cuban link choker chain with no pendant.The customized stainless steel Audemars Piguet Royal Oak 15500 watch features 30 carats of VVS diamonds. It is made by Saki Mihalakos, owner of Saki Diamonds, a Jacksonville-based jewelry company. Without diamonds, it reportedly costs $27,800, and with diamonds, the price rises to $70K.In one of his Instagram posts, where Sanders wears the pendant “2” diamond chain, he also shows off this watch. The signal caller bought this watch in 2022 when he played college football for Jackson State.“That’s my watch on his wrist,” Saki Mihalakos said via Complex Sports in Sept. 2023. “It’s beautiful to see my piece on that stage, but it doesn’t happen like that as if you’re not good to that person. I’m grateful to be a part of that.I’m grateful for the attention that it’s caught, and the beauty of it all is that it goes along with the vision I had for Saki Diamonds, to build not just a nationwide brand but a global brand.”Also Read: “Tip toed all around that question”: Tom Brady took a moment of silence before speaking on Cleveland Browns rookie QB Shedeur Sanders
Article Summary: Cleveland Browns rookie quarterback Shedeur Sanders is known for his extravagant jewelry collection. He wore a massive ‘Legendary’ chain reportedly worth over $100K to the 2025 NFL Draft. Sanders also owns a custom-made Audemars Piguet Royal Oak 15500 diamond watch.

Article Title: “So good to be…”: Gisele Bündchen and Tom Brady enter the 2025 holiday season with new marriages and major life changes

Article Title: LeBron James celebrates 41st birthday as Los Angeles Lakers teammates surprise him after practice
Article Text:
(Image Source - Getty Images)

Los Angeles Lakers throws surprise a birthday celebration for LeBron James

LeBron James’ 41st birthday sparks reflection inside the Los Angeles Lakers locker room

The Los Angeles Lakers transformed a regular practice day into a big locker-room party for LeBron James ’ 41st birthday. The Lakers' practice session at Crypto.com Arena quickly turned into a celebration that showed the team’s bond and admiration for its longest-serving player. A well-orchestrated surprise, featuring cake, singing, and lots of laughter, provided James with a rare break in the midst of a tough season.The reaction spoke volumes. Grins appeared, cameras were rolling, and teammates gathered around, making the moment feel more like a family gathering than a franchise event. It wasn’t flashy or overly staged. It was intimate. The celebration gave a peek into how much James still matters to the team and why even the simplest actions around him hold significance.The celebrations began right after the Lakers finished their practice at the Crypto.com Arena. Head coach JJ Redick took the lead by unveiling a two-layer birthday cake that had special touches celebrating James' legendary "King" nickname. On top of that cake was a golden crown and displayed an image of James' personal brand logo.Rookie forward Adou Thiero took the spotlight next, grabbing a mic to sing "Happy Birthday to You" in front of the whole team.Chris Mañon, another rookie, joined in the fun, adding his voice to the birthday wishes. They caught the moment on video, which went viral, perfectly capturing the team's playful spirit.As the song came to an end, James' teammates rushed in for hugs and cheers, making the birthday boy laugh as he tried to break free. "Get off," James said to his teammates, grinning widely during the hug fest. The official Lakers Instagram account later shared the video with the caption, “Squad celebrated the King’s birthday after practice.”The celebration gave James a short break, as he's been juggling serious training with team bonding for a while now. It showed how much his teammates respect him, especially since he's stepping into his 23rd season — a real nod to his professionalism in a league where staying power is hard to come by.James' birthday got his Lakers teammates thinking about how he keeps shining at 41. Center Jaxson Hayes chatted with Olympics.com before the Pistons game and credited James' careful routine as the key to his ongoing success.“Definitely his preparation. I’ve never seen someone so prepared. He has his whole schedule lined up, he sticks to it every day. He’s the first one in the gym every day, and that’s just a testament to him and how great of a player he is,” Hayes said.Hayes mentioned something that really resonated with the team about James' impact. The forward's habit of showing up early and putting in the work sets a benchmark that inspires everyone, contributing to the camaraderie displayed during the birthday surprise. Coach JJ Redick, who was born in the same year as James, provided a different but relatable viewpoint during a media session the day before the celebration.“I have trouble getting out of bed in the morning and got to get an injection on my knee. My body is old and broken. It’s like that [maxim]: If you don’t use it, you lose it. And once I stopped using it, I lost it all.”James talked about his ongoing fight with age in a post-practice interview two days ago, mentioning a Nike ad series where he takes on "Father Time." “When I did the father of time commercial thing, I’m in a battle with him, and I would like to say that I’m kicking his ass on the back nine,” James joked with ESPN's Dave McMenamin, making everyone laugh with his golf analogy.These conversations took place before the birthday, giving us a better understanding of why the team's gesture seemed so heartfelt. At 41, James is still the emotional backbone of the Lakers, mixing his veteran experience with his powerful performance on the court.Also Read: Ben Simmons reportedly puts his NBA return on hold after earning $270 million in contracts for a surprising reason
Article Summary: Los Angeles Lakers throw surprise a birthday celebration for LeBron James. A well-orchestrated surprise, featuring cake, singing, and lots of laughter, provided James with a rare break in the midst of a tough season. The celebration gave a peek into how much James still matters to the team.
